title: Self-reinforcing expectancy effects on pain: Behavioral and brain mechanisms

author: Marieke Jepma, Faculty of Social and Behavioural Sciences, Leiden University

segmentation: I will talk about learning in the first domain, namely learning to predict pain and how this can be influenced by our prior expectancies.
Um?
It is well known that Spain, like many other types of experiences and judgments, can be strongly shaped by what we expect or by our prior beliefs.
Prominent example of this is placebo analgesia, where the expectancy of getting an analgesic treatment can produce pain relief even though there's no actual treatments administered.
